qa_list.question: What are students' rights regarding their education records according to FERPA?
qa_list.answer: Students have the right to review and request amendment of their education record if they believe it is inaccurate or misleading. They can also request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction.

qa_list.question: What are students' rights regarding the disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records?
qa_list.answer: Students have the right to consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records, except for cases where FERPA authorizes disclosure without consent.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated?
qa_list.answer: Students can file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office.

qa_list.question: Who is responsible for answering questions about Student Privacy Rights, FERPA or filing a complaint?
qa_list.answer: John Papinchak, University Registrar in Enrollment Services can be contacted at jp7p@andrew.cmu.edu.

qa_list.question: What is the Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC) at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: The CPDC is a centralized career center staffed by seasoned professionals who provide career exploration, experiential learning, and networking opportunities for students and alumni.

qa_list.question: Where is the Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC) located?
qa_list.answer: The CPDC is located on the Lower Level of the University Center.

qa_list.question: What is CMU's career and professional development model based on?
qa_list.answer: CMU's career and professional development model is grounded in discipline-specific career development, experiential learning, and employer relations shaped by strong connections with the university's seven academic colleges.

qa_list.question: What are the key elements of CMU's Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC) success?
qa_list.answer: The CPDC's success is founded upon a solid understanding of career and professional development theory, integration of technology, and an unwavering commitment to providing personalized attention towards meeting the unique individual needs of students, alumni, and employers.

qa_list.question: What can be found on page 32 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: Information about professional development opportunities at Carnegie Mellon University is found on page 32 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Office of the Assistant Vice Provost for Graduate Education (AVPGE)?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Assistant Vice Provost for Graduate Education offers a robust schedule of professional development opportunities.

qa_list.question: Who can attend the professional development programs offered by AVPGE?
qa_list.answer: Some are geared towards specific populations (master’s students, PhD students at the beginning of their program, graduate students seeking tenure track positions), while others are open to all graduate students.

qa_list.question: Where can a full schedule of these programs be found?
qa_list.answer: A full schedule of programs can be found at http://www.cmu.edu/graduate/.

qa_list.question: What is the combined mission of Carnegie Mellon's three main libraries?
qa_list.answer: Their combined mission is to provide access and help graduate students find information, teach them how to evaluate available information, and use reliable sources.

qa_list.question: What services do the University Libraries offer for graduate students?
qa_list.answer: They offer digital resources and services including off-campus/wireless access to databases and e-journals.

qa_list.question: Are there other libraries open to Carnegie Mellon graduate students?
qa_list.answer: Yes, two neighboring libraries are also open to them: the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh and University of Pittsburgh Libraries.

qa_list.question: Where can one find information about all mentioned library locations, hours, online resources, and FAQ’s?
qa_list.answer: This information can be found on the University Libraries website.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Computing Services at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Their purpose is to provide computing resources and services for students, faculty, and staff.

qa_list.question: Where can one find more information about these services?
qa_list.answer: More information can be found on the Computing Services website at www.cmu.edu/computing/

qa_list.question: Where is Computing Services located?
qa_list.answer: Computing Services is located in Cyert Hall 285.

qa_list.question: What services does Computing Services provide for Carnegie Mellon students, faculty members and staff members?
qa_list.answer: Computing Services develops, maintains, and supports the computing infrastructure for Carnegie Mellon students, faculty members and staff members. This includes the campus wired and wireless networks, public computer labs or “clusters,” cable television and telephone services, computing related documentation and support through the Help Center.

qa_list.question: What additional information can be found on the Computing Services website?
qa_list.answer: The website contains addition information regarding The Help Center hours, location and contact information, computing cluster hours and location, the Carnegie Mellon web portal, computing security and policies and guidelines.

qa_list.question: How can students get assistance from Computing Services?
qa_list.answer: Students can email the Help Center at advisor@andrew.cmu.edu with questions and for assistance.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Family and Dependents Resources page on The Graduate Student Assembly website?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Family and Dependents Resources page on The Graduate Student Assembly website is to maintain a resource page for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about resources for their spouses, domestic partners, and families?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about resources for their spouses, domestic partners, and families on the Graduate Student Assembly website.

qa_list.question: In which page of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook can students find more information about family and dependents resources?
qa_list.answer: Students can find more information about family and dependents resources in Page 33 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for The Graduate Student Assembly website's resource page for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students?
qa_list.answer: The URL for The Graduate Student Assembly website's resource page for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students is https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/Resources-for.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Affiliate ID Cards at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Affiliate ID Cards are available for spouses and domestic partners of graduate students that allow them to access Carnegie Mellon’s campus.

qa_list.question: Who is eligible for Affiliate ID Cards at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Affiliate ID Cards are available through The HUB to spouses and partners of graduate students who are enrolled for the current academic year in a full-time graduate degree program.

qa_list.question: How long is an Affiliate ID Card valid at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The card is valid for one year.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about student and affiliate ID cards at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: For more information about student and affiliate ID cards, please visit: https://www.cmu.edu/idplus/idcards/sponsored.html.

qa_list.question: Does Carnegie Mellon extend benefits to domestic partners of students?
qa_list.answer: Yes, Carnegie Mellon extends certain benefits to domestic partners of students.

qa_list.question: Where can eligible students elect benefits for their domestic partners at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Eligible students may elect benefits for their domestic partners through the registration process orchestrated by the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs, 3rd floor Warner Hall.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about the benefits available for domestic partners at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Information regarding the benefits available for domestic partners, eligibility for domestic partner benefits, registration instructions and forms can be located at: https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean/domestic-partner/index.html.

qa_list.question: Does Carnegie Mellon University offer housing to graduate students?
qa_list.answer: No, the university does not currently offer housing to graduate students.

qa_list.question: What resources does the Office of Housing and Dining Services provide for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Housing and Dining Services provides community housing information to assist graduate students who are seeking housing in the communities surrounding the university, including information on the legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists and the off-campus housing database.

qa_list.question: Does the university offer housing to graduate students?
qa_list.answer: No, the university does not currently offer housing to graduate students.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find information about community housing near the university?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can find information about community housing near the university at https://www.cmu.edu/housing/. The Office of Housing and Dining Services provides this information, which includes details on legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists, and an off-campus housing database.

qa_list.question: What services are offered through the Office of Housing and Dining Services?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Housing and Dining Services offers dining services and operations. They operate dining locations open around campus in academic buildings, Hunt Library, and the University Center. These locations offer flexible hours with options from early morning through late night.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about dining locations, hours of operation, graduate student dining plans forms, nutritional information, and weekly menus for dining locations?
qa_list.answer: Students can find this information on the Dining Service website. The site contains details about dining locations, their hours of operation, graduate student dining plans forms, nutritional information, and weekly menus for each location.

qa_list.question: Is there any mention of parking and transportation in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: Yes, parking and transportation are mentioned on page 34 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for the Dining Service website?
qa_list.answer: The URL for the Dining Service website is https://www.cmu.edu/dining/. This site provides information about dining locations, hours of operation, graduate student dining plans forms, nutritional information, and weekly menus for each location.

qa_list.question: What kind of services does the Office of Housing and Dining Services provide to students?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Housing and Dining Services provides dining services and operations. They operate dining locations open around campus in academic buildings, Hunt Library, and the University Center.

qa_list.question: Does the university offer housing to graduate students?
qa_list.answer: No, the university does not currently offer housing to graduate students. However, they provide community housing information to assist graduate students who are seeking housing in the communities surrounding the university.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for the page where students can find information about community housing near the university?
qa_list.answer: The URL for this information is https://www.cmu.edu/housing/. The Office of Housing and Dining Services provides details on legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists, and an off-campus housing database.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find information about parking and availability at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can find information about parking and availability, parking policies, transportation options, and Port Authority Transit usage with a valid university ID on the Parking and Transportation Services site.

qa_list.question: Where is the Parking and Transportation Services office located?
qa_list.answer: The Parking and Transportation Services office is located in the lower level of the University Center, LL#8.

qa_list.question: What are the permit rates for parking areas on campus?
qa_list.answer: The varying permit rates can be found on the website.

qa_list.question: What happens if a car is parked in a permit area without a permit or at an expired meter?
qa_list.answer: Parking and Transportation Services will ticket any car parked in a permit area without a permit or at an expired meter.

qa_list.question: Does the city monitor parking along Margaret Morrison, Frew, and Tech Streets?
qa_list.answer: Yes, the city monitors the metered parking along these streets and will ticket at expired meters as well.

qa_list.question: What services does Carnegie Mellon University offer for transportation within campus?
qa_list.answer: The university offers shuttle and escort services operated through University Police. The Shuttle Service operates several routes within Oakland, Squirrel Hill, and Shadyside areas, as well as to university sites located outside of the main campus.

qa_list.question: What is the Escort Service offered by Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Escort Service offers vehicle routes within a radius of campus between 6:30 pm-6 am daily.

qa_list.question: Where can students find up-to-date shuttle and escort schedules, pick-up/drop-off locations, routes, and usage policies?
qa_list.answer: Information regarding these details can be found at: www.cmu.edu/police/shuttleandescort/

qa_list.question: What services does Carnegie Mellon University offer for copying, printing, and mailing?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon offers community members easy access to UPS, copy centers, printing and mailing services, and postal services.

qa_list.question: What services does Carnegie Mellon offer for copying and printing?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon offers copy centers, printing and mailing services.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about campus events at the University Center?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about campus events by visiting the Information Desk at the University Center or calling 412-268-2107.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Wright-Rogal Chapel in the University Center?
qa_list.answer: The Wright-Rogal Chapel serves as a public prayer room for students and faculty at Carnegie Mellon.

qa_list.question: What services does the University Center provide to its visitors?
qa_list.answer: The University Center provides retail stores, dining services, fitness rooms, scheduling space, student organizations and a public prayer room for students.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about the campus eateries at the University Center?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about campus eateries by visiting the University Center website or contacting the Information Desk.

qa_list.question: What is the function of the University Center in Carnegie Mellon's campus?
qa_list.answer: The University Center serves as a central hub for students to interact, get involved and enjoy new experiences on campus.

qa_list.question: Where can students find ATM services at the University Center?
qa_list.answer: Students can find ATM services within the retail stores located in the University Center.

qa_list.question: What is the location of PNC Bank on Carnegie Mellon's campus?
qa_list.answer: PNC Bank is located at the University Center for students to access banking services.

qa_list.question: How can students schedule space in the University Center for their events or activities?
qa_list.answer: Students can schedule space in the University Center by visiting the website and using the scheduling tool provided there.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of MIIS Graduate Student Handbook mentioned in the text?
qa_list.answer: The MIIS Graduate Student Handbook provides guidelines for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What facilities does Carnegie Mellon offer related to athletics and fitness?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon offers intercollegiate athletics, intramural sports, physical education classes, club sports, aerobics classes in the University Center and Skibo Gym, occasional workshops and instruction related to fitness and health.

qa_list.question: Where is the Athletics Office located?
qa_list.answer: The Athletics Office is located in the Skibo Gymnasium.

qa_list.question: What facilities are available at Skibo Gym for athletic activities?
qa_list.answer: Skibo Gym has courts for basketball, volleyball, badminton, as well as weight-training and aerobic equipment.

qa_list.question: Where can students find recreational facilities at the University Center?
qa_list.answer: The University Center’s recreational facilities include an eight-lane pool, racquetball and squash courts, aerobics room, fitness center and gym for basketball and volleyball.

qa_list.question: What is the requirement to use athletic and fitness facilities at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: All users must present a current Carnegie Mellon Card to use these facilities.

qa_list.question: How can students register for CMU Alert?
qa_list.answer: Students can register for CMU Alert through the website.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of CMU Alert?
qa_list.answer: CMU Alert sends voice and/or text messages to registered phones in the event of a campus emergency that threatens public safety or during tests of the system in the spring and fall semesters.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about CMU Alert?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about CMU Alert on the website.

qa_list.question: What is mentioned in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook related to CMU Alert?
qa_list.answer: Information about CMU Alert is mentioned in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, specifically on page 36.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Appendix A in this document?
qa_list.answer: Appendix A provides a list of key resources for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University, including those related to student support, academic and research assistance, health and wellness, safety measures, and other important information.

qa_list.question: Which office is responsible for assisting individuals with disabilities?
qa_list.answer: The Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities is the key resource that assists students with disabilities at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What are some of the resources available to support graduate student academic and research needs?
qa_list.answer: Some of the resources for supporting graduate student academic and research needs include Computing and Information Resources, Student Academic Success Center, University Libraries, Research at CMU, and Office of Research Integrity & Compliance.

qa_list.question: What is the name of the handbook that contains Appendix A?
qa_list.answer: The MIIS Graduate Student Handbook contains Appendix A with key resources for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about the Ethics Reporting Hotline?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about the Ethics Reporting Hotline in Appendix A of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Office of International Education at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of International Education supports international students and provides resources for study abroad opportunities, language support, and cultural events.

qa_list.question: Which office is responsible for handling policy against retaliation at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Policy Against Retaliation falls under the jurisdiction of an unspecified office within the university, as mentioned in Appendix A.

qa_list.question: What is the location where students can find information about health and wellness resources at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about health and wellness resources, including Counseling and Psychological Services, University Health Service, Campus Wellness, Religious and Spiritual Life Initiatives, and University Police, in Appendix A.

qa_list.question: What is the name of the page where students can find information about key resources for graduate student support?
qa_list.answer: The information about key resources for graduate student support can be found on Page 37 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the main purpose of the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs provides central support for all master’s and doctoral students, as well as academic programs, with a focus on supporting graduate student success at Carnegie Mellon.

qa_list.question: What are some examples of resources offered through the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs?
qa_list.answer: Examples of resources offered through the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs include a website with university resources, bi-monthly newsletters to all graduate students, professional development seminars and workshops, GSA/Provost Conference Funding Grants, GSA/Provost Small Research Grants (GuSH), consultations on issues related to the graduate student experience.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Office of the Dean of Students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Dean of Students provides central leadership of the metacurricular experience at Carnegie Mellon including the coordination of student support. Vice President of Student Affairs and Dean of Students Gina Casalegno leads the Division of Student Affairs which includes the offices and departments listed below (not an exhaustive list).

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Graduate Student Assembly at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Graduate Student Assembly partners with many other offices and organizations, such as the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs, to support the holistic graduate student educational experience.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Division of Student Affairs at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Division of Student Affairs includes the offices and departments listed below (not an exhaustive list) which provides central leadership of the metacurricular experience at Carnegie Mellon.

qa_list.question: What is the enrollment information for Domestic Partner MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The enrollment information for Domestic Partner can be found in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, Page 38.

qa_list.question: What is the contact email of Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs?
qa_list.answer: The contact email for Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs is grad-ed@cmu.edu

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find university resources at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can find university resources on the website of Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs.

qa_list.question: What are some examples of professional development seminars and workshops offered through the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs?
qa_list.answer: Examples of professional development seminars and workshops offered through the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs include GSA/Provost Conference Funding Grants, GSA/Provost Small Research Grants (GuSH), and Professional Development Seminars.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Office of the Dean of Students?
qa_list.answer: The Office of the Dean of Students manages registration and childbirth/maternity accommodations, as well as the Student Emergency Support Funding process.

qa_list.question: What types of support funding are available for enrolled students?
qa_list.answer: There are three forms of support funding: emergency student loans, maternity loans, and the Tartan Emergency Support Fund.

qa_list.question: Where can students find additional information about various types of funding?
qa_list.answer: Students will be provided with additional information during a consultation meeting with a member of the Dean of Students team.

qa_list.question: Are tuition costs eligible for Student Emergency Support Funding?
qa_list.answer: No, tuition costs are not eligible for Student Emergency Support Funding.

qa_list.question: What additional resources are available for graduate students at the university?
qa_list.answer: Additional resources include College Liaisons and the Student Support Resources team.

qa_list.question: Who are College Liaisons and what do they do?
qa_list.answer: College Liaisons are senior members of the Division of Student Affairs who work with departments and colleges addressing student concerns across a wide range of issues. They are identified on the student SIO page in the Important Contacts list.

qa_list.question: What does the Student Support Resources team offer?
qa_list.answer: The Student Support Resources team offers an additional level of support for students who are navigating any of a wide range of life events. Staff members work in partnership with campus and community resources to provide coordination of care and support appropriate to each student’s situation.

qa_list.question: What is included in the Division of Student Affairs?
qa_list.answer: (not an exhaustive list): registration and childbirth/maternity accommodations, the Office of the Dean of Students, the Student Emergency Support Funding process, College Liaisons, and the Student Support Resources team.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Division of Student Affairs?
qa_list.answer: The Division of Student Affairs includes (not an exhaustive list): registration and childbirth/maternity accommodations in the Office of the Dean of Students or on their website, the Student Emergency Support Funding process, College Liaisons, and the Student Support Resources team.

qa_list.question: What are some departments included in the Division of Student Affairs?
qa_list.answer: The Division of Student Affairs includes Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation, Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC), Center for Student Diversity and Inclusion, Cohon University Center, Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS), Dining Services, Office of Community Standards and Integrity (OCSI), Office of Student Leadership, Involvement, and Civic Engagement (SLICE), and University Health Services (UHS).

qa_list.question: What is the mission of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion?
qa_list.answer: The mission of the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion is to actively cultivate a strong, diverse, and inclusive community capable of living out Carnegie Mellon University's values of diversity and inclusion while advancing research, creativity, learning, and development that changes the world.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion?
qa_list.answer: Students can find more information about the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion on page 39 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the name of the department that focuses on career and professional development?
qa_list.answer: The department that focuses on career and professional development is called Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC).

qa_list.question: Which department provides health services to students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: University Health Services (UHS) provides health services to students at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What is the name of the center that promotes student involvement and civic engagement?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Student Leadership, Involvement, and Civic Engagement (SLICE) is responsible for promoting student involvement and civic engagement at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What are the main departments included in the Division of Student Affairs?
qa_list.answer: The main departments included in the Division of Student Affairs are Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation, Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC), Center for Student Diversity and Inclusion, Cohon University Center, Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS), Dining Services, Office of Community Standards and Integrity (OCSI), and Office of Student Leadership, Involvement, and Civic Engagement (SLICE).

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) department?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) department is to provide mental health support and resources for students at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What services does Dining Services offer to students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Dining Services offers a variety of dining options on campus, including cafeterias and food trucks, for students at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What is the name of the department that handles student conduct and integrity?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Community Standards and Integrity (OCSI) is responsible for handling student conduct and integrity at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What are the main dimensions that The Center enhances to provide an inclusive and transformative student experience?
qa_list.answer: The Center enhances dimensions such as access, success, campus climate, and intergroup dialogue.

qa_list.question: Which programs does the Center support for historically underrepresented students at both graduate and undergraduate levels?
qa_list.answer: The Center supports and connects historically underrepresented students, including those who are first in their family to attend college. Initiatives include First generation/first in family to attend college programs, LGBTQ+ Initiatives, Race and ethnically focused programs (like Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series), Women’s empowerment programs (including Graduate Women’s Gatherings), Transgender and non-binary student programs.

qa_list.question: What is the mission of The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The mission of The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. They work to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.

qa_list.question: How can students who need accommodations begin the process at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation process.

qa_list.question: Which types of disabilities are supported by The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Disability Resources supports students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities.

qa_list.question: How can students get more information about the accommodation process and ask questions at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students can get more information about the accommodation process by emailing access@andrew.cmu.edu or calling (412) 268-6121.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation aims to enhance teaching and learning experiences by providing resources, support, and opportunities for professional development.

qa_list.question: What is the website address of The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation?
qa_list.answer: The website address of The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation is www.cmu.edu/teaching.

qa_list.question: What are students with physical, sensory, cognitive or emotional disabilities encouraged to do?
qa_list.answer: Students with physical, sensory, cognitive or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self-identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request needed accommodations.

qa_list.question: Where can students get more information about the process?
qa_list.answer: Students can get more information about the process by directing their questions to access@andrew.cmu.edu or calling (412) 268-6121.

qa_list.question: Where is this text located?
qa_list.answer: This text is located in A.1.5 Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation at www.cmu.edu/teaching.

qa_list.question: What does the Office of Disability Resources offer?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Disability Resources offers confidential consultation services and professional development programs to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors of record during their time at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What is the goal of the Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation?
qa_list.answer: The goal of the Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies.

qa_list.question: What does MIIS stand for in this context?
qa_list.answer: MIIS stands for Graduate Student Handbook in this context.

qa_list.question: Where is the information about the Eberly Center's goal located?
qa_list.answer: The information about the Eberly Center's goal can be found on Page 40 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the consultation services offered by the Office of Disability Resources?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the consultation services offered by the Office of Disability Resources is to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors of record during their time at Carnegie Mellon University and as future faculty members at other institutions.

qa_list.question: What does the text suggest about the process for requesting accommodations?
qa_list.answer: The text suggests that students with physical, sensory, cognitive or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self-identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request needed accommodations.

qa_list.question: What are some ways that Carnegie Mellon University supports graduate student instructors?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon University offers various programs and services to support graduate student instructors, including campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events and the Future Faculty Program. The Eberly Center also assists departments in creating customized programs for their graduate student instructors.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Graduate Student Assembly at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) represents and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at CMU. It is composed of representatives from different graduate programs and departments who work to improve the graduate student experience at various levels of the university. GSA passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C., and acts on behalf of all graduate student interests.

qa_list.question: How is the Graduate Student Assembly funded?
qa_list.answer: The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) is funded by the Student Activities Fee from all graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: What are some recent accomplishments of the Graduate Student Assembly?
qa_list.answer: The Graduate Student Assembly has made a difference in implementing its strategic plan, advocating for graduate student issues and needs at various levels of the university.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about Eberly Center support for graduate students?
qa_list.answer: Students can find specific information about Eberly Center support for graduate students by visiting www.cmu.edu/teaching/graduatestudentsupport/index.html.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Future Faculty Program at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Future Faculty Program is designed to help participants be effective and efficient in their teaching roles as graduate student instructors.

qa_list.question: How does the Eberly Center assist departments in supporting graduate student instructors?
qa_list.answer: The Eberly Center assists departments in creating customized programs to meet the specific needs of their graduate student instructors, helping them improve their teaching skills and effectiveness.

qa_list.question: What is the role of representatives from different graduate programs and departments in the Graduate Student Assembly?
qa_list.answer: Representatives from different graduate programs and departments play a crucial role in the Graduate Student Assembly by advocating for their peers' interests, improving the overall graduate student experience at CMU, and implementing strategic plans to address various needs.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events?
qa_list.answer: Campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events are designed to provide new graduate student instructors with accessible and actionable ways to improve their teaching skills, helping them become more effective in their roles.

qa_list.question: What does GSA offer graduate students at CMU?
qa_list.answer: GSA offers an expanding suite of social programming on and off-campus to bring graduate students from different departments together and build a sense of community.

qa_list.question: Where is the Graduate Student Lounge located at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The Graduate Student Lounge is located on the 3rd floor of the Cohon University Center.

qa_list.question: What kind of resources does GSA maintain for graduate students?
qa_list.answer: GSA maintains a website of graduate student resources on and off-campus.

qa_list.question: How is the GSA/Provost Conference Funding Program managed?
qa_list.answer: The GSA/Provost Conference Funding Program is managed by the Graduate Education Office through continued funding for professional development and research conferences.

qa_list.question: What does OIE stand for in the context of CMU?
qa_list.answer: OIE stands for Office of International Education at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: Where can international graduate and undergraduate students go for assistance at CMU?
qa_list.answer: International graduate and undergraduate students can seek assistance from the Office of International Education (OIE) at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: Where is the information about MIIS Graduate Student Handbook located?
qa_list.answer: The information about MIIS Graduate Student Handbook can be found on Page 41 of the handbook.

qa_list.question: How can students get involved with GSA at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Students can contact GSA through <gsa@cmu.edu> to get involved, stop by their office in the Cohon University Center Room 304 or become a representative for their department.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of GSA's continued funding for professional development and research conferences?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of GSA's continued funding for professional development and research conferences is to run the GSA/Provost Conference Funding Program and GSA/Provost GuSH Research Grants.

qa_list.question: What services does OIE provide for students?
qa_list.answer: OIE provides advising on personal, immigration, study abroad, academic, and social and acculturation issues; presents programs of interest such as international career workshops, tax workshops, and cross-cultural and immigration workshops; posts pertinent information to students through email and the OIE website; and conducts orientation and pre-departure programs.

qa_list.question: What resources are available for military veterans at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Military veterans can find information on applying for veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, and non-educational resources through the Veterans and Military Community website. There are also links and connections to veteran resource in the Pittsburgh community.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline is to confidentially report suspected unethical activity, violations of university policy, or violations of law. Topic areas for reporting may include academic and student life, bias reporting, discriminatory harassment/sexual misconduct/Title IX, employee misconduct, employment related issues, environmental health and safety/pandemic safety, financial matters, health and wellness, information systems and data privacy, public safety & criminal activity, research & intellectual property.

qa_list.question: How can graduate students apply for veteran education benefits at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can find information on applying for veteran education benefits through the Veterans and Military Community website.

qa_list.question: What is the contact information of the ROTC and Veteran Affairs Coordinator at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The contact information of the ROTC and Veteran Affairs Coordinator can be reached at uro-vaedbenefits@andrew.cmu.edu or 412-268-8747.

qa_list.question: What is the URL of the Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline?
qa_list.answer: The URL of the Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline is https://www.cmu.edu/hr/resources/ethics-hotline.html.

qa_list.question: What are some topic areas for reporting through the Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline?
qa_list.answer: Some topic areas for reporting include academic and student life, bias reporting, discriminatory harassment/sexual misconduct/Title IX, employee misconduct, employment related issues, environmental health and safety/pandemic safety, financial matters, health and wellness, information systems and data privacy, public safety & criminal activity, research & intellectual property.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Veterans and Military Community website at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Veterans and Military Community website is to provide information on applying for veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, and non-educational resources.

qa_list.question: What are some links and connections available through the Veterans and Military Community website?
qa_list.answer: The Veterans and Military Community website provides links and connections to veteran resource in the Pittsburgh community.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the phone number provided in the text?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the phone number provided in the text is for students, faculty and staff to anonymously file a report.

qa_list.question: Where can one visit to make such reports?
qa_list.answer: One can visit cmu.ethicspoint.com to make such reports.

qa_list.question: Who receives the submissions made through this system?
qa_list.answer: The submissions made through this system are reported to appropriate university personnel.

qa_list.question: How are these submissions handled by the university personnel?
qa_list.answer: These submissions are handled discreetly by the university personnel.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the hotline mentioned in the text?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the hotline mentioned in the text is not specified.

qa_list.question: According to the Policy Against Retaliation, what happens if someone makes a good faith report of a suspected violation at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: If someone makes a good faith report of a suspected violation at Carnegie Mellon University, they are protected from retaliation.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for additional details regarding the Policy Against Retaliation?
qa_list.answer: The URL for additional details regarding the Policy Against Retaliation is https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html

qa_list.question: What are some of the resources provided by Computing Services at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Some of the resources provided by Computing Services at Carnegie Mellon University include campus wired and wireless networks, printing, computer labs, file storage, email, software catalog.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for the Computing Services website?
qa_list.answer: The URL for the Computing Services website is https://www.cmu.edu/computing/

qa_list.question: How can students get assistance from Computing Services at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students can get assistance from Computing Services by visiting the Computing Services Help Center, which is available at 412-268-4357 (HELP) or it-help@cmu.edu.

qa_list.question: What are some of the resources provided by the Student Academic Success Center?
qa_list.answer: Some of the resources provided by the Student Academic Success Center include communication support, academic advising, tutoring services, and study skills workshops.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for the Student Academic Success Center?
qa_list.answer: The URL for the Student Academic Success Center is https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/

qa_list.question: What services do communicators offer?
qa_list.answer: Communicators convey ideas clearly and effectively on a variety of STEM and humanities topics. They also support communication excellence on essays, technical reports, oral presentations, slides, data visualization, advanced English language learning, and many other project types.

qa_list.question: What modes of support are offered by communicators?
qa_list.answer: Support is offered in several modes: One-on-one communication tutoring (in-person or Zoom synchronous meeting)--Clients meet with a consultant to improve the logic, clarity, and flow of writing or presentation and receive expert feedback that will strengthen a project.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of clients uploading drafts, instructor prompts, and rubrics when making an appointment?
qa_list.answer: Clients upload these documents so consultants can use specific criteria to give relevant feedback that will strengthen a project.

qa_list.question: What is the role of consultants in helping clients improve their projects?
qa_list.answer: Consultants support communication excellence on essays, technical reports, oral presentations, slides, data visualization, advanced English language learning, and many other project types.

qa_list.question: What kind of feedback do consultants provide to clients?
qa_list.answer: Expert feedback that will strengthen a project.

qa_list.question: When can clients bring in a project for support?
qa_list.answer: Clients can bring in a project at any stage including brainstorming ideas, organizing thoughts, responding to instructor feedback, or putting finishing touches on the final draft.

qa_list.question: What is the benefit of one-on-one communication tutoring?
qa_list.answer: Clients meet with a consultant to improve the logic, clarity, and flow of writing or presentation.

qa_list.question: How do communicators help clients in advanced English language learning?
qa_list.answer: Communicators support communication excellence on essays, technical reports, oral presentations, slides, data visualization, and many other project types.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Zoom synchronous meeting in one-on-one communication tutoring?
qa_list.answer: Clients meet with a consultant to improve the logic, clarity, and flow of writing or presentation.

qa_list.question: What is STEM?
qa_list.answer: STEM stands for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics. It refers to academic disciplines that are typically considered non-artistic, such as those that use scientific methods to study the natural world.

doc_text:
their education record if they believe they are inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction;
• consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records, except to the extent that FERPA authorizes disclosure without consent; file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated.

For questions about Student Privacy Rights, FERPA or filing a complaint, contact John Papinchak, University Registrar, jp7p@andrew.cmu.edu, in Enrollment Services.
7.7 Professional Development
https://www.cmu.edu/career/
The Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC) at Carnegie Mellon is a centralized career center staffed by a team of seasoned and highly educated professionals who orchestrate the career exploration, experiential learning, and career networking needs of students and alumni.
CMU's career and professional development model is grounded in discipline-specific career development, experiential learning, and employer relations shaped by strong connections with the university's seven academic colleges. The center's success is founded upon a solid understanding of career and professional development theory, integration of technology, and an unwavering commitment to providing personalized attention towards meeting the unique individual needs of students, alumni, and employers. The CDPC is located on the Lower Level of the University Center, 412-268-2064
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 32


The Office of the Assistant Vice Provost for Graduate Education (AVPGE) offers a robust schedule of professional development opportunities. Some are geared towards a specific population (master’s students, PhD students at the beginning of their program, graduate students seeking tenure track positions, etc.) and others are open to all graduate students (time management, balancing, staying healthy). A full schedule of programs can be found at: http://www.cmu.edu/graduate/.
7.8 University Libraries
http://search.library.cmu.edu
There are three main libraries at Carnegie Mellon: Hunt Library, Mellon Institute Library and Engineering & Science Library with the combined mission of providing access and help to graduate students in finding the information needed, teaching graduate students to evaluate available information and use reliable sources. The libraries’ digital resources and services, including off-campus/ wireless access to databases and e-journals, offer online access. There are also two neighboring libraries open to Carnegie Mellon graduate students: Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh and University of Pittsburgh Libraries. Visit the University Libraries website for information about all mentioned library locations and hours, on-line resources, and FAQ’s.
7.9 Computing Services
www.cmu.edu/computing/
Computing Services is located in Cyert Hall 285. Computing Services develops, maintains, and supports the computing infrastructure for Carnegie Mellon students, faculty members and staff members. This includes the campus wired and wireless networks, public computer labs or “clusters,” cable television and telephone services, computing related documentation and support through the Help Center. In addition, Computing Services provides standard classroom technologies for over 100 lecture halls, classrooms, and seminar rooms across campus. The website contains addition information regarding The Help Center hours, location and contact information, computing cluster hours and location, the Carnegie Mellon web portal, computing security and policies and guidelines. Students can email the Help Center at advisor@andrew.cmu.edu with questions and for assistance.
7.10 Family and Dependents Resources
The Graduate Student Assembly website maintains a resource page for spouses, domestic partners and families of graduate students: https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/Resources-for-
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 33


Graduate-Students/Partner-and-Family-Resources.html, including The Student Parent Association, new mother rooms, and links to resources around campus and the Pittsburgh area.
Affiliate ID Cards are available for spouses and domestic partners of graduate students that allow them to access Carnegie Mellon’s campus. These cards are available through The HUB to spouses and partners of graduate students who are enrolled for the current academic year in a full-time graduate degree program. The card is valid for one year. For more information about student and affiliate ID cards, please visit: https://www.cmu.edu/idplus/idcards/sponsored.html.
7.11 Domestic Partner Registration
Carnegie Mellon extends certain benefits to domestic partners of students. Eligible students may elect benefits for their domestic partners through the registration process orchestrated by the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs, 3rd floor Warner Hall. Information regarding the benefits avail-able for domestic partners, eligibility for domestic partner benefits, registration instructions and forms can be located at: https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean/domestic- partner/index.html.
7.12 Housing
The university does not currently offer housing to graduate students. The Office of Housing and Dining Services does provide community housing information to assist graduate students who are seeking housing in the communities surrounding the university, including information on the legal aspects of renting an apartment, moving checklists and the off- campus housing database. This information can be located at: https://www.cmu.edu/housing/.
7.13 Dining
https://www.cmu.edu/dining/
Dining services and operations are offered through the Office of Housing and Dining Services. The office operates dining locations open around campus in academic buildings, Hunt Library, and the University Center. These locations offer flexible hours with options from the early morning through late night. The Dining Service website contains information about dining locations, hours of operation, graduate student dining plans forms, nutritional information, and weekly menus for dining locations.
7.14 Parking and Transportation
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 34


https://www.cmu.edu/parking/
Graduate students will find information about parking and availability, parking policies, transportation options and Port Authority Transit usage with a valid university ID on the Parking and Transportation Services site. The Parking and Transportation Services office is located in the lower level of the University Center, LL#8. There is limited parking on campus and the varying permit rates can be found on the website. All parking areas of campus are either by permit, metered or by the hour in the garage. Parking and Transportation Services will ticket any car parked in a permit area without a permit or at an expired meter. The city monitors the metered parking along Margaret Morrison, Frew and Tech Streets and will ticket at expired meters as well.
The university offers shuttle and escort services operated through University Police. The Shuttle Service operates several routes within Oakland, Squirrel Hill and Shadyside areas, as well as to university sites located outside of the main campus. The Escort Service offers vehicle routes within a radius of campus between 6:30 pm-6 am daily. Information regarding up-to-date shuttle and escort schedules, pick-up/drop-off locations, routes and usage policies can be found at: www.cmu.edu/police/shuttleandescort/.
7.15 Copying, Printing and Mailing Services
Carnegie Mellon offers community members easy access to UPS, copy centers, printing and mailing services, and postal services.
Mailing and postal services https://www.cmu.edu/postoffice/
Printing and copy services https://www.cmu.edu/tartanink/copyprint/index.html
7.16 University Center
www.cmu.edu/university-center
The University Center is a centerpiece of the campus that provides a space for special events, physical fitness, student organizations and various activities, as well as accommodating retail and dining services. As the campus crossroads, the University Center functions as a place for students to interact, get involved and enjoy new experiences. Visit the University Center website for information about campus eateries, ATMs and PNC Bank, fitness rooms and schedules, retail stores, scheduling University Center space, the public prayer room, student organizations and the Wright-Rogal Chapel.
The University Center Information Desk is the location if you want to know about upcoming campus events or have questions about Carnegie Mellon in general, call the Information Desk at 412-268-2107. The Information Desk not only provides information about campus events,
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 35


but also sells postage stamps, makes copies, sends faxes, distributes campus maps, manages a lost & found, and has information brochures about Pittsburgh and the campus.
7.17 Athletic/Fitness Facilities
www.cmu.edu/athletics
For the participant or the spectator, Carnegie Mellon offers intercollegiate athletics, intramural sports, physical education classes and club sports. The Athletics Department also offers aerobics classes in the University Center and Skibo Gym as well as occasional workshops and instruction related to fitness and health. The Athletics Office is located in the Skibo Gymnasium.
Skibo Gym facilities include courts for basketball, volleyball, badminton, as well as weight- training and aerobic equipment. The University Center’s recreational facilities include an eight-lane pool, racquetball and squash courts, aerobics room, fitness center and gym for basketball and volleyball. All users must present a current Carnegie Mellon Card to use these facilities.
7.18 CMU Alert
www.cmu.edu/alert
CMU Alert sends voice and/or text messages to registered phones in the event of a campus emergency that threatens public safety or during tests of the system in the spring and fall semesters. Students can register for CMU Alert through the website.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 36


A Appendix
Appendix A
2022-2023

Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs ● Office of the Dean of Students ● Center for Student Diversity and Inclusion ● Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities ● Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence and Educational Innovation ● Graduate Student Assembly ● Office of International Education ● Veterans and Military Community ● Ethics Reporting Hotline ● Policy Against Retaliation

MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 37


Shuttle and Escort Services ● The WORD
A.1 Key Resources for Graduate Student Support
A.1.1 Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs
www.cmu.edu/graduate; grad-ed@cmu.edu The Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs provides central support for all master’s and doctoral students, as well as academic programs, with a focus on supporting graduate student success at Carnegie Mellon.
Examples of resources offered through the Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs include- but are not limited to:
▪ Website with university resources, contact information for CMU programs and
services, calendar of events related to graduate students
▪ Bi-monthly newsletter to all graduate students with information on activities,
resources, and opportunities
▪ Professional Development Seminars and Workshops ▪ GSA/Provost Conference Funding Grants ▪ GSA/Provost Small Research Grants (GuSH) ▪ Consultations on issues related to the graduate student experience
The Office of Graduate and Postdoc Affairs also works with the colleges and departments by informing and assisting in developing policy and procedures relevant to graduate students and working with departments on issues related to graduate students. Additionally, we partner with many other offices and organizations, such as the Graduate Student Assembly, to support the holistic graduate student educational experience.
A.1.2 Office of the Dean of Students
https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean
The Office of the Dean of Students provides central leadership of the metacurricular experience at Carnegie Mellon including the coordination of student support. Vice President of Student Affairs and Dean of Students Gina Casalegno leads the Division of Student Affairs which includes the offices and departments listed below (not an exhaustive list).
Graduate students will find the enrollment information for Domestic Partner
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 38


Registration and Childbirth/Maternity Accommodations in the Office of the Dean of Students or on their website. This Office also manages the Student Emergency Support Funding process. There are three forms of support funding for enrolled students: emergency student loans, maternity loans, and the Tartan Emergency Support Fund. These funds are made available through generous gifts of alumni and friends of the university as well as support from student organizations, Undergraduate Student Senate, and the Graduate Student Assembly. Students will be provided with additional information about the various types of funding during a consultation meeting with a member of the Dean of Students team. Tuition costs are not eligible for Student Emergency Support Funding.
Additional resources for graduate students include College Liaisons and the Student Support Resources team (https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/resources/index.html). College Liaisons are senior members of the Division of Student Affairs who work with departments and colleges addressing student concerns across a wide range of issues. College Liaisons are identified on the student SIO page in the Important Contacts list. The Student Support Resources team offers an additional level of support for students who are navigating any of a wide range of life events. Student Support Resources staff members work in partnership with campus and community resources to provide coordination of care and support appropriate to each student’s situation.
The Division of Student Affairs includes (not an exhaustive list):
▪ Athletics, Physical Education and Recreation ▪ Career and Professional Development Center (CPDC) ▪ Center for Student Diversity and Inclusion ▪ Cohon University Center ▪ Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) ▪ Dining Services ▪ Office of Community Standards and Integrity (OCSI) ▪ Office of Student Leadership, Involvement, and Civic Engagement (SLICE) ▪ University Health Services (UHS) ▪ Wellness Initiatives
A.1.3 Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion
https://www.cmu.edu/student-diversity/
Diversity and inclusion have a singular place among the values of Carnegie Mellon University. The Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion actively cultivates a strong, diverse, and inclusive community capable of living out these values and advancing research, creativity, learning and development that changes the world.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 39


The Center offers resources to enhance an inclusive and transformative student experience in dimensions such as access, success, campus climate and intergroup dialogue. Additionally, the Center supports and connects historically underrepresented students and those who are first in their family to attend college in a setting where students’ differences and talents are appreciated and reinforced, both at the graduate and undergraduate level. Initiatives coordinated by the Center include, but are not limited to:
First generation/first in family to attend college programs • LGBTQ+ Initiatives • Race and ethnically focused programs, including Inter-University Graduate Students of Color Series (SOC) and PhD SOC Network
Women’s empowerment programs, including Graduate Women’s Gatherings (GWGs)
Transgender and non-binary student programs
A.1.4 Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities
http://www.cmu.edu/disability-resources/
The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University has a continued mission to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. We work to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation process.
Students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self- identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request needed accommodations. Any questions about the process can be directed to access@andrew.cmu.edu, or call (412) 268- 6121.
A.1.5 Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence & Educational Innovation
www.cmu.edu/teaching
We offer a wide variety of confidential, consultation services and professional development programs to support graduate students as teaching assistants or instructors of record during their time at Carnegie Mellon University and as future faculty members at other institutions. Regardless of one's current or future teaching context and duties, our goal is to disseminate evidence-based teaching strategies in
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 40


ways that are accessible and actionable. Programs and services include campus-wide Graduate Student Instructor Orientation events and our Future Faculty Program, both of which are designed to help participants be effective and efficient in their teaching roles. The Eberly Center also assists departments in creating and conducting customized programs to meet the specific needs of their graduate student instructors. Specific information about Eberly Center support for graduate students is found at www.cmu.edu/teaching/graduatestudentsupport/index.html.
A.1.6 Graduate Student Assembly
www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/index.html
The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) is the branch of Carnegie Mellon Student Government that represents, and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at CMU. GSA is composed of representatives from the different graduate programs and departments who want to improve the graduate student experience at the different levels of the university. GSA is funded by the Student Activities Fee from all graduate students. GSA passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C. on behalf of graduate student issues and needs, and otherwise acts on behalf of all graduate student interests. Our recent accomplishments are a testament to GSA making a difference, and steps to implementing the vision laid out by the strategic plan. https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/gsa/About-the-GSA/Strategic- Plan.html.
GSA offers an expanding suite of social programming on and off-campus to bring graduate students from different departments together and build a sense of community. GSA is the host of the Graduate Student Lounge on the 3rd floor of the Cohon University Center- a great place to study or meet up with friends. GSA also maintains a website of graduate student resources on and off-campus. Through GSA’s continued funding for professional development and research conferences, the GSA/Provost Conference Funding Program and GSA/Provost GuSH Research Grants are able to run, as managed by the Graduate Education Office. As we move forward, GSA will continue to rely on your feedback to improve the graduate student experience at CMU. Feel free to contact us at <gsa@cmu.edu> to get involved, stop by our office in the Cohon University Center Room 304 or become a representative for your department.
A.1.7 Office of International Education (OIE)
http://www.cmu.edu/oie/
Carnegie Mellon hosts international graduate and undergraduate students who come from more than 90 countries. The Office of International Education (OIE) is the liaison to the University for all non-immigrant students and scholars, as well the repository for
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 41


study abroad opportunities and advisement. OIE provides many services including: advising on personal, immigration, study abroad, academic, and social and acculturation issues; presenting programs of interest such as international career workshops, tax workshops, and cross- cultural and immigration workshops; international education and statistics on international students in the United States; posting pertinent information to students through email and the OIE website and conducting orientation and pre-departure programs.
A.1.8 Veterans and Military Community
http://www.cmu.edu/veterans/
Military veterans are a vital part of the Carnegie Mellon University community. Graduate students can find information on applying for veteran education benefits, campus services, veteran’s groups at CMU, and non-educational resources through the Veterans and Military Community website. There are also links and connections to veteran resource in the Pittsburgh community. The ROTC and Veteran Affairs Coordinator can be reached at uro-vaedbenefits@andrew.cmu.edu or 412-268-8747.
A.1.9 Carnegie Mellon Ethics Hotline
https://www.cmu.edu/hr/resources/ethics-hotline.html
The health, safety and well-being of the university community are top priorities at Carnegie Mellon University. CMU provides a hotline that all members of the university community should use to confidentially report suspected unethical activity, violations of university policy, or violations of law. Topic areas for reporting may include, but are not limited to: • Academic and Student Life • Bias Reporting • Discriminatory Harassment / Sexual Misconduct / Title IX • Employee Misconduct • Employment Related • Environmental Health and Safety / Pandemic Safety • Financial Matters • Health and Wellness • Information Systems and Data Privacy • Public Safety & Criminal Activity • Research & Intellectual Property
Students, faculty and staff can anonymously file a report by calling 1-844-587-0793 or visiting cmu.ethicspoint.com. All submissions are reported to appropriate university personnel and handled discreetly.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 42


The hotline is NOT an emergency service. For emergencies, call University Police at 412- 268-2323.
A.1.10 Policy Against Retaliation
It is the policy of Carnegie Mellon University to protect from retaliation any individual who makes a good faith report of a suspected violation of any applicable law or regulation, university Policy or procedure, any contractual obligation of the university, and any report made pursuant to the Carnegie Mellon University Code of Business Ethics and Conduct.
Additional details regarding the Policy Against Retaliation are available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and- governance/whistleblower.html
A.2 Key Offices for Academic & Research Support
A.2.1 Computing and Information Resources
www.cmu.edu/computing
Computing Services maintains and supports computing resources for the campus community, including the campus wired and wireless networks, printing, computer labs, file storage, email and software catalog. As members of this community, we are all responsible for the security of these shared resources. Be sure to review the Safe Computing (https://www.cmu.edu/computing/safe/) section and the University Computing Policy (https://www.cmu.edu/policies/information- technology/computing.html)
Visit the Computing Services website (https://www.cmu.edu/computing/) to learn more. For assistance the Computing Services Help Center is available at 412-268-4357 (HELP) or it- help@cmu.edu.
A.2.2 Student Academic Success Center
https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/
Student Academic Support Programs
A.2.2.1 Communication and Language Support: Communication Support: The program offers free consultations for all CMU students on their written, oral, and visual projects. Our trained communication consultants help
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 43


communicators convey ideas clearly and effectively on a variety of STEM and humanities topics. Consultants support communication excellence on essays, technical reports, oral presentations, slides, data visualization, advanced English language learning, and many other project types. Clients can bring in a project at any stage including brainstorming ideas, organizing thoughts, responding to instructor feedback, or putting finishing touches on the final draft. Support is offered in several modes:
One-on-one communication tutoring (in-person or Zoom synchronous meeting)--Clients meet with a consultant to improve the logic, clarity, and flow of writing or presentation and receive expert feedback that will strengthen a project. When making an appointment, clients upload a draft, instructor prompts, and rubrics so consultants can use specific criteria to give relevant feed
